city.description: City, district, suburb, town, or village.
city.title: City

postal_code.description: ZIP or postal code. If french postal code, it should be a pure number, without letters.
postal_code.title: Postal Code

line1.description: Address line 1 (e.g., street, PO Box, or company name).
line1.title: Line1

line2.description: Address line 2 (e.g., apartment, suite, unit, or building).
line2.title: Line2

SIREN.description: SIREN number for billing and tax purposes. Usually located at the top or the very bottom of the document. (small text), and located alongside the other billing informations
SIREN.title: Siren

VAT_number_thinking.description:
The VAT number is present for billing and tax purposes. Usually located at the top or the very bottom of the document, and located alongside the other billing informations (small text).
In France the VAT number format is FR {2 digits validation key} {first 9 digits SIREN number} so try use the SIREN number if available to help validate the VAT number.
Document your reasoning for the VAT number identification:
1. Look for numbers prefixed with 'FR' or labeled as 'TVA', 'VAT', or 'n° TVA'
2. Verify the format matches FR followed by key of 2 digits and 9 digits of SIREN number
3. Note where you found it in the document

Example: "Found VAT number FR12345678901 in footer next to SIREN number"

If multiple possible VAT numbers exist, explain your choice. If none found, state "No VAT number identified in document.
VAT_number_thinking.title: Vat Number Thinking

client_city.description: City, district, suburb, town, or village.
client_city.title: Client City

client_postal_code.description: ZIP or postal code. If french postal code, it should be a pure number, without letters.
client_postal_code.title: Client Postal Code

thinking.description:
Document your analysis of the goods information from the source document. Include:

1. Description of what's being transported
2. Any reference numbers or codes found
3. Special handling requirements
4. Equipment needs
5. Safety considerations
6. Documentation requirements
7. The presence of returnable Euro pallets (it has to be explicitly stated that the pallets are EU pallets in the source document in the sender section (not in the legal mentions))

*Some observations you may consider about the weight:*
- Sometimes the weight appears in tons, or kilograms. If the unit is not specified, assume it is in kilograms. However, the weight may appear like "12T400" which means 12.4 tons.
- Some weight examples: "1500" -> 1500 kg, "1T500" -> 1.500 tons -> 1500 kg, "7T565" -> 7.565 tons -> 7565 kg, "12 tons" -> 12000 kg, "14 tonnes" -> 14000 kg

*Example of thinking output:*
```
Source indicates: 
- 12 pallets of automotive parts
- Reference: ORDER123, BATCH456
- Requires forklift for unloading
- Non-stackable items
- Fragile goods warning labels needed"
- Weight is in displayed in tons - its value is 5.4 tons, which is equivalent to 5400 kg.
```
List all relevant details found in the source document. Do not make assumptions about information that isn't explicitly stated.
thinking.title: Thinking

weight.description: Weight of the dangerous good (in tons)
weight.title: Weight

UN_code.description: UN code of the dangerous good
UN_code.title: Un Code

UN_label.description: UN label of the dangerous good
UN_label.title: Un Label

UN_class.description: UN class of the dangerous good
UN_class.title: Un Class

UN_packing_group.description: UN packing group of the dangerous good
UN_packing_group.title: Un Packing Group

ADR_tunnel_code.description: ADR tunnel code of the dangerous good
ADR_tunnel_code.title: Adr Tunnel Code

date.description: Date of the delivery. ISO 8601 Date Format: YYYY-MM-DD
date.title: Date

start_time.description: Start time of the delivery. ISO 8601 Time Format: hh:mm
start_time.title: Start Time

end_time.description: End time of the delivery. ISO 8601 Time Format: hh:mm. Must be greater than or equal to the start_time.
end_time.title: End Time

loading_meters_thinking.description:
A loading meter (LM) is a measurement of the cargo space occupied in a truck, calculated based on the item’s footprint relative to the truck’s standard internal width of 2.4 meters. This measurement helps determine how much linear floor space is needed to transport the goods efficiently.

If loading meters are provided in the source (often labeled as Mètre linéaire (ML) or Mètre plancher (MPL)), use that value directly, noting it as “Using provided value of X loading meters.”

If not, calculate as follows:

	1.	For each item: (length × width) / 2.4.
	2.	Sum all calculated loading meters.

For example:

	•	Item 1 is 3m × 1.2m, so it takes (3 × 1.2) / 2.4 = 1.5 loading meters.
	•	Item 2 is 2m × 1.6m, so it takes (2 × 1.6) / 2.4 = 1.33 loading meters.

Total loading meters: 1.5 + 1.33 = 2.83 meters

For each item, write down the formula, insert values, and compute explicitly.
Take your time to think rigourously. Do not hesitate to write down intermediate steps. WARNING: VOLUME WILL NOT BE IN ml, this is the unit used for loading meters - ml stands for metres lineaires.
loading_meters_thinking.title: Loading Meters Thinking

volume_thinking.description:
Volume represents the total space occupied by an item in cubic meters, calculated as (length × width × height).

If volume is provided in the source, use that value directly and note it as, “Using provided value of X cubic meters.”

If not, calculate as follows:

	1.	For each item: length × width × height.
	2.	Sum the volumes of all items for the total volume.

Example:

	•	Item 1: 2m × 1m × 1.5m = 3 cubic meters
	•	Item 2: 1.5m × 1m × 1m = 1.5 cubic meters

Total volume: 3 + 1.5 = 4.5 cubic meters

For each item, write down the formula, insert values, and compute explicitly. Take your time to ensure accuracy, and write intermediate steps if necessary.
volume_thinking.title: Volume Thinking

thinking.description:
Document your analysis of the goods information from the source document. Include:

1. Description of what's being transported
2. Any reference numbers or codes found
3. Special handling requirements
4. Equipment needs
5. Safety considerations
6. Documentation requirements
7. The presence of returnable Euro pallets (it has to be explicitly stated that the pallets are EU pallets in the source document in the sender section (not in the legal mentions))

Example: "Source indicates: 
- 12 pallets of automotive parts
- Reference: ORDER123, BATCH456
- Requires forklift for unloading
- Non-stackable items
- Fragile goods warning labels needed"
- Weight is displayed in tons 

List all relevant details found in the source document. Do not make assumptions about information that isn't explicitly stated.
thinking.title: Thinking

packing_thinking.description:
Document your analysis of the packing information. Consider:
1. How many total units and what types
2. Pallet sizes and quantities
3. Whether pallets are explicitly marked as EUR/EPAL
4. Additional parcels or packages
5. Any special packing requirements

Example: "Source indicates:
- 8 standard EUR pallets (marked EPAL)
- 3 oversized pallets 120x120
- 5 additional cardboard boxes
- Non-stackable warning"

List all packing details found in source. Do not make assumptions.
packing_thinking.title: Packing Thinking

number_eur_pallet.description: Number of pallets that follow the European standard, i.e., marked as something like EUR or EPAL. If not explicitly mentioned, set to 0.
number_eur_pallet.title: Number Eur Pallet

date.description: Date of the pickup. ISO 8601 Date Format: YYYY-MM-DD
date.title: Date

start_time.description: Start time of the pickup. ISO 8601 Time Format: hh:mm
start_time.title: Start Time

end_time.description: End time of the pickup. ISO 8601 Time Format: hh:mm. Must be greater than or equal to the start_time.
end_time.title: End Time

delivery_datetime.description: Delivery date and time. Must be after the pickup date and time, can be later on the pickup date.

observations.description:
Include all relevant delivery information. This includes:
	•	Reference numbers (e.g., delivery refs, order numbers)
	•	Contact details (e.g., names, roles, extensions)
	•	Dock/door numbers, access codes, and specific entrance instructions
	•	Required documentation and any special equipment needs
	•	Unloading bay specs, timing preferences, and site access instructions
	•	Parking info, unloading procedures, safety protocols, and any additional notes near recipient info
When you write observations, write them in the same language as the email and the documents. If they are in French, write them in French, if they are in English, write them in English.
observations.title: Observations

observations.description:
Include all relevant information for pickup and sender details. This includes:
	•	Reference numbers (e.g., order or booking refs)
	•	Contact details (e.g., names, roles, extensions)
	•	Dock/door numbers, access codes, and navigation instructions
	•	Required documentation and special equipment needs
	•	Loading bay specs, timing preferences, and site access instructions
	•	Parking info, specific entrance locations, and any additional sender notes
When you write observations, write them in the same language as the email and the documents. If they are in French, write them in French, if they are in English, write them in English.
observations.title: Observations

thinking.description:
Document your analysis of the shipment information. Include:

1. How you identified this as a distinct shipment
2. Key reference numbers and their sources
3. Relationships between pickup and delivery points
4. Any special routing or timing requirements
5. Document references (CMR, waybills, etc.)

Example: "Source shows:
- Single shipment identified by CMR #12345
- Pickup from warehouse A to delivery point B
- Must deliver within 24h window
- References found: Order #789, Customer PO #456"

Document your reasoning process and any key decisions made in interpreting the shipment structure.
thinking.title: Thinking

shipment_id_thinking.description: Document your reasoning for including or excluding this Shipment ID. You can usually chose to ommit the Shipment ID if there is only one shipment and the most relevant shipment ID is equal to the Booking ID.
shipment_id_thinking.title: Shipment Id Thinking

shipment_id.description: Unique identifier for the shipment, most often the CMR number or CMR reference, used for tracking and documenting transport details. Can also be client / sender reference number. If several numbers are provided and the situation is ambiguous, pick the most logical one, and put other numbers in the observation field.
shipment_id.title: Shipment Id

total_price.description: Net price of the booking order (excluding taxes)
total_price.title: Total Price

billing_memo.description:
Document all billing-related information and special instructions. This includes:
        • Payment terms and conditions
        • Special billing arrangements or requirements
        • Discount agreements or surcharges
        • Required billing documentation or references
        • Cost allocation instructions
        • Billing schedule or timing requirements
        • Additional charges (e.g., fuel surcharge, waiting time)
        • Any other financial notes or instructions

When documenting billing information, maintain consistency with source document language and format.
Include all reference numbers and codes exactly as provided.
billing_memo.title: Billing Memo

thinking.description:
Document the specific facts from the source that determine vehicle requirements. For example:
- List any explicitly mentioned vehicle specifications
- Note any temperature requirements stated
- Record loading/unloading equipment mentioned
- Include any access restrictions specified

Example: 'Source specifies: refrigerated transport required, -20°C, loading dock not available, tail lift needed.'

Only include information that is explicitly stated in the source document. Do not make assumptions about requirements that aren't clearly specified.
thinking.title: Thinking

vehicle_type.description:
Primary vehicle classification:
- 'Tractor': for semi-trailer trucks (Tracteur)
- 'Carrier': for rigid trucks (Porteur) 
- 'Light Vehicle': for vans and smaller commercial vehicles (Véhicule léger)
vehicle_type.title: Vehicle Type

body_type.description:
Type of cargo body/trailer:
- 'Tautliner': curtainside trailer (Tautliner/Transpalette)
- 'Dry Van': box trailer (Fourgon)
- 'Refrigerated': temperature-controlled (Réfrigéré)
- 'Flatbed': open platform (Plateau)
- 'Tanker': liquid cargo (Citerne)
body_type.title: Body Type

tail_lift.description: Indicates if the vehicle is equipped with a hydraulic tail lift for ground-level loading/unloading without dock access (Hayon élévateur)
tail_lift.title: Tail Lift

crane.description: Indicates if the vehicle is equipped with a loading crane/HIAB for self-loading and unloading of heavy cargo (Grue)
crane.title: Crane

thinking.description:
Document your analysis of the overall booking confirmation. Include:

1. Document type identification and confidence
2. Key parties involved (client, carrier, etc.)
3. Overall structure of the shipments
4. Critical booking details and requirements
5. Any ambiguities or unclear elements

Example: "Analysis shows:
- Clear booking confirmation document from ABC Corp
- Contains 2 distinct shipments under single booking reference
- Client identified as ABC Corp from letterhead
- Total value and payment terms clearly stated
- All required signatures present"

Explain your reasoning for key decisions made in interpreting the document structure.
thinking.title: Thinking

booking_id.description: Unique identifier for the booking used for billing reference
booking_id.title: Booking Id

number_of_shipments.description: Number of shipments in the booking. Most frequently 1, but can be 2,3 to 10-20
number_of_shipments.title: Number Of Shipments

shipments_thinking.description:
Document your analysis for each shipment. For each shipment identified in the document, include:

1. A detailed description of the goods being transported, including any reference numbers, dangerous goods information, and packing details.
2. The sender’s information, including the company name, address, contact details, and any relevant observations about the pickup process.
3. The recipient’s information, including the company name, address, contact details, and any relevant observations about the delivery process.
4. Any trucking constraints, including vehicle requirements, loading/unloading equipment, and specific transport conditions.

Example:
"Shipment Analysis:
1: SSP BOC - 4 EUR pallets, 10ML, 7,623 kg  (UN 3082, liquid, 9, GE III)
2: AMC(31) BOS 2249 - 8 pallets, 7ML, 3,240 kg
3: VETISOL BOS 2195 - 10 pallets, 9ML, 3,780 kg
4: VETISOL BOS 2282 - 6 pallets, 5ML, 2,020 kg
5: SOERMEL BOS 2264 - 2 pallets, 8ML, 1,300 kg (UN 3077, solid, 9, GE III)
6: DUMOULIN BOS 2281 - 15 pallets, 11ML, 10,400 kg
7: SOLUSTIL BOS 1764 - 20 pallets, 12ML, 24,800 kg Refrigerated vehicle (-20°C)
8: TECMA TAR 323 - 1 pallet, 2ML, 1,475 kg
9: PAILLET BOS 2290 - 8 pallets, 10ML, 4,945 kg

Ensure that each shipment is clearly detailed with all relevant information. Do not omit any critical details.
Most frequently, there is going to be one or two shipments in the document, but sometimes you can have a massive number of shipments on several lines, more like a table containing a long list of shipments.
In this case, you should create a shipment for each line of the table, it can go to 10-20 shipments sometimes.
shipments_thinking.title: Shipments Thinking
